title: Penetrating Neck Trauma
diagnosis_topic: Penetrating Neck Injury (Zone II) – Stable vs. Unstable Management, Aerodigestive Evaluation
setup_script: “A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the left side of the neck during an altercation. On arrival, he is agitated and bleeding from a 4 cm transverse wound in Zone II of the neck. His vital signs are: BP 100/60, HR 122, RR 28, O2 saturation 92% on room air. On exam, there is active venous bleeding, subcutaneous emphysema, and hoarseness of voice. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident begins with ATLS survey
dynamic_flow.reply: “Primary survey shows airway threatened with stridor, expanding hematoma, and ongoing bleeding.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about hemodynamic status
dynamic_flow.reply: “Currently, the patient is tachycardic at 122 with BP 100/60 and saturating 92% on room air.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident classifies patient as unstable (airway threatened and active bleeding)
dynamic_flow.reply: “This patient is unstable and requires immediate operative exploration. How will you secure the airway?”
“The airway is distorted with bleeding obscuring the cords. What is your next step?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs a surgical airway
dynamic_flow.reply: “You perform a cricothyroidotomy successfully. The patient is oxygenating. What is your next step?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays exploration in the unstable patient
dynamic_flow.reply: “What is the definitive management for an unstable patient with penetrating Zone II neck trauma?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident classifies patient as stable (no airway compromise, bleeding controlled)
If the patient were stable, what diagnostic studies would you obtain prior to operative intervention?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “CT angiography shows contrast extravasation adjacent to the left internal jugular vein and subcutaneous emphysema tracking toward the hypopharynx. What is your next step?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds to operative neck exploration
dynamic_flow.reply: “What incision and exposure will you use to explore Zone II?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident identifies venous injury intraoperatively
dynamic_flow.reply: “On exploration, there is a partial transection of the left internal jugular vein with ongoing bleeding. How will you manage this?”
“There is a 2 cm laceration of the left thyroid cartilage with subcutaneous emphysema. How will you evaluate for associated aerodigestive injury?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident does not mention intraoperative endoscopy
dynamic_flow.reply: “Is there anything else you would like to do intraoperatively to assess the airway and esophagus?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs flexible bronchoscopy and esophagoscopy
dynamic_flow.reply: “Flexible bronchoscopy shows no tracheobronchial injury. Esophagoscopy reveals a 1 cm mucosal tear in the cervical esophagus. How will you manage this injury?”
“After primary repair and drainage, what are your postoperative priorities regarding antibiotics, nutrition, airway management, and monitoring for complications?”
“The patient develops fever and increasing neck tenderness with purulent drain output. What concerns do you have and what will you do next?”

critical_decision_points: Differentiation of stable vs. unstable patient management in penetrating neck trauma
Airway control in the unstable patient (surgical airway vs. failed intubation)
Immediate operative exploration for unstable patient
Use of CT angiography and selective operative management in stable patient
Mandatory flexible bronchoscopy and esophagoscopy intraoperatively to exclude aerodigestive injury
Technical management of vascular and esophageal injuries

anchors.1: 1: Fails to differentiate stable vs. unstable pathways
anchors.2: 3: Recognizes instability but incomplete reasoning for stable patient workup
anchors.3: 5: Correctly distinguishes unstable patient (immediate OR) vs. stable patient (CTA, selective exploration) and identifies need for intraoperative esophagoscopy + bronchoscopy

anchors.2: 3: Secures airway and bleeding control but misses endoscopic evaluation
anchors.3: 5: Excellent judgment throughout with appropriate triage, airway, operative decision-making, and adjunctive studies

anchors.1: 1: Disorganized, unable to articulate trauma priorities
anchors.2: 3: Communicates plan but misses sequence or rationale
anchors.3: 5: Clear, systematic ATLS-based communication, explains reasoning and anticipates complications

anchors.1: 1: Inadequate understanding of neck zones and workup
anchors.2: 3: Understands exposures and vascular control but misses aerodigestive evaluation
anchors.3: 5: Excellent knowledge of stable vs. unstable pathways, exposures, vascular/airway/esophageal repair principles, and mandatory intraoperative endoscopic adjuncts

anchors.1: 1: Ignores trauma team input, poor leadership
anchors.3: 5: Excellent leadership, collaboration with trauma/ENT/ICU teams, patient-centered approach
